hypothesis.title: Synaptic Pruning Dysfunction in Autism Spectrum Disorders
hypothesis.description: Aberrant microglial-mediated synaptic pruning during critical developmental periods contributes to the altered connectivity patterns observed in autism spectrum disorders, and modulating complement cascade activity could provide therapeutic benefits
key_findings: Increased microglial activation in ASD brain tissue
Altered complement protein expression in ASD models
Synaptic pruning defects in mouse models of ASD
CX3CR1 knockout mice show ASD-like behaviors
proposed_experiments: Single-cell RNA sequencing of microglia in ASD brain tissue
Complement inhibition studies in ASD mouse models
Longitudinal imaging of synaptic pruning in development
hypothesis.clinical_relevance: Could lead to early intervention strategies for ASD
